q:
Suppose you are working on Linux OS. There is an external hardware or device driver connected to the system which allows kernel to access it and extend functionality. This is considered as module. These are often called as objects of the kernel. Consider a module “XYZ” which is available for root users. Now, your task is to perform a few operations on modules.
Based on the mentioned information, choose the statements which are correct.

Statements

  1. lsmod is used to load all the modules

     

  2. module is used to append a module to other

     

  3. “modprobe XYZ” command will load the module XYZ

     

  4. insmod and modprobe work similarly

Suppose XYZ is working on Linux OS. He/she has logged in as a root user. For this, he/she has first decided to create a file namely “sample.txt” but it needs to be created using echo with “Hello” as content. After that, he/she wants to change the permissions of the file in such a way that the owner will have the access to read, write and execute it, any other user group can both write and read; and the remaining users/world will only have the access to read/view the file.
Based on the above information, help XYZ to do the task by picking up the suitable commands for the given statements:

Statements
1. Command for creating the file?
2. Command for changing permission?
3. The structure of permission shown in the terminal when verifying the file (in rwx format)?

Options

  1. echo ‘Hello’ > sample.txt
chmod 765 sample
-rwxrw-r-x
  2. echo ‘Hello’ sample.txt
chmod 7654 sample
-rwxrw-r-x

     

  3. echo ‘Hello’ > sample.txt
chmod 764 sample
-rwxrw-r--

     

  4. echo ‘Hello’ > sample.txt
chmod 765 sample
-rwxrw----

Suppose you are working on Linux OS. You are given a task to create an additional layer between the hard disk and the file system. This should allow users to resize or move file systems. It will however partition the hard disks for managing data logically.
How will you reduce or shrink the size of this partition so that the size of the file system will become 10GB?

Options

  1. umount
resize2fs
lvreduce
  2. resize2fs
lvreduce
umount

     

  3. umount
lvreduce
resize2fs

     

  4. resize2fs
umount
lvreduce

While working on Linux OS, you want to retrieve the hostname of the system and further change it to a different name i.e. “mail.sample.com”, keeping in mind that hostname should be unique with the system and hostname will have the restrictions.
According to the given information, is it possible to change the hostname? What will be the command to do so?

Options

  1. No 
Hostname is in wrong format
  2. No
We can’t change it once named

     

  3. Yes
sudo hostnamectl hostname mail.sample.com

     

  4. Yes
sudo hostnamectl set-hostname mail.sample.com

X applied for a Linux operator role in PQR company. He/she wants to find the multiple parameters with just one command.
As discussed, by executing the command, you need to get the current time of the system, total duration of the system from which it has been running, total no. of logged-in users, and the CPU load average time of the system. Which of the following commands will get the said information?

In Linux OS, there is a root user available by default. Now, you want to create a new user to give him/her access to the working environment. The name of the user should be “linuxoperator” and the password should be “newuser”.

Answer the following:

  1. What is the command to do the above process?
  2. Where can you check whether the account has been created or not?

Options

  1. sudo adduser linuxoperator
system settings > user accounts > linuxoperator
  2. sudo adduser linuxoperator -p newuser
system settings > user accounts > linuxoperator

     

  3. sudo add linuxoperator -p newuser
system settings > user accounts > linuxoperator

     

  4. sudo adduser linuxoperator
system settings > linuxoperator

In the Linux OS, Sysadmin manages system performance, configurations, and keeps a track of servers available. If you are a sysadmin and you have to shut down the system for 5 minutes for maintenance purposes, along with a message "Maintenance Work".
Which of the following commands has to be executed for completing the given task?

Options

  1. shutdown 5 "Maintenance Work"

     

  2. shut down 5 -m "Maintenance Work"

     

  3. close 5min "Maintenance Work"

     

  4. close 5min "Maintenance Work"

To improve the query performance, you need to manage the mongod process using customization of the mongod server.

Perform the following operations using the Mongo Shell:
1. Change the default data directory for mongod to "/mongodb/server/mydir/".
2. Start the mongod listening on non-default port 27019.
3. Start the mongod process as a daemon and store its output to a file 'newmongod.log' at the path "/mongodb/log/newlog/".
4. Shut down the mongod with timeoutSecs set to 5 from the Mongo Shell.

Which of the following set of commands will perform the above operations successfully?

Options

1.

> mongod --dir /mongodb/server/mydir/
> mongod --configport 27019
> mongod --db --logfile /mongodb/log/newlog/newmongod.log
> db.killServer({timeout : 5})

2.

> mongod --setpath /mongodb/server/mydir/
> mongod --port 27019
> mongod --daemon --log /mongodb/log/newlog/newmongod.log
> db.shutdownServer({timeoutAfterSecs : 5})

3.

> mongod --path /mongodb/server/mydir/
> mongod --port 27019
> mongod --service --logpath /mongodb/log/newlog/newmongod.log
> db.runCommand({shutdownServer, timeoutSecs : 5})

4.

> mongod --dbpath /mongodb/server/mydir/
> mongod --port 27019
> mongod --fork --logpath /mongodb/log/newlog/newmongod.log
> db.shutdownServer({timeoutSecs : 5})

You have a collection 'asianews' in a database 'newsupdates'. You want to collect detailed information about Database queries executed against this database.

You need to perform the following operations:
1. View all commands that are currently running/in-progress for the database 'newsupdates'.
2. Set a profiler that collects data for commands that take longer than 25 slowms.

Which of the following will perform the above operation successfully?

Options

1.

> use newsupdates
> db.findOp()
> db.addProfilingl(0, { slowms: 25 })

2.

> use newsupdates
> db.getcurrentOp()
> db.addProfilingLevel(2, { slowms: 25 })

3.

> use newsupdates
> db.currentOp()
> db.setProfilingLevel(1, { slowms: 25 })

4.

> use newsupdates
> db.currentOp()
> db.profilingLevel($set: 2, { slowms: 25 })

You are currently logged in a MongoDB Shell as an administrator. You are using the database 'admin' and you have a collection 'user_transactions'. You need to take the backup of certain contents of your database by exporting its content into '.bson' files.
You need to do the following:
1. Take the backup of the all documents from collection 'user_transactions' where 'transaction_status' is 'processed'.
2. Store the backup at new location 'C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump'.
3. View the contents of backup file 'user_transactions'.bson'.
4. Import the backup file 'user_transactions.bson' that is created at 'C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions' into a new database 'testdb' .
Which of the following set of commands will perform the above operations successfully?

Options

1.

> use admin
> mongodump --o C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump -db admin -collection user_transactions --criteria "{status: processed}"
> jsondump C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions.json
> restoredump -d testdb ''C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions"

2.

> use admin
> mongodump --out C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump -d admin -c user_transactions --query "{status: processed}"
> bsondump C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions.bson
> mongorestore ''C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions" -d testdb

3.

> use admin
> mongodump --out gzip C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump -d admin -c user_transactions --gssapiServiceName "{status: processed}"
> mongodump C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions
> restorecollection ''C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions" -d testdb

4.

> use admin
> mongodump --gzip C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump -d admin -c user_transactions --queryFile "{status: processed}"
> jsondump C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions.json
> mongo --restore -d admin ''C:\Users\user\Desktop\datadump\admin\user_transactions" -d testdb
